clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Peer Support on Quality of Life in Recently Diagnosed Breast Cancer Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness of Peer Support on Quality of Life in Recently Diagnosed Breast Cancer Patients - a Randomized Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This study examines effectiveness of peer support of breast cancer patients. Half of the participants received peer support via telephone in addition to usual care and another half are give the usual care only.

detailed_description.textblock:
Seriously sick people need social support to maintain their quality of life. Social support may be given by peers, who have experienced the same.
In this study voluntary participants with recently diagnosed breast cancer were randomly allocated to intervention (N=130) or control (N=130) group. The intervention group received, in addition to usual care, peer support via telephone 1-5 times according to their own preference. The control group received usual care only. Peer support was given by volunteered breast cancer survivors who were educated for giving peer support.

primary_outcome.measure: A change of health-related quality of life (HRQoL).
primary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 3, 6 and 12 months later.
primary_outcome.description: HRQoL was assessed with a generic 15D instrument.

primary_outcome.measure: A change of health-related quality of life (HRQoL).
primary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to 3, 6 and 12 months later.
primary_outcome.description: HRQoL was assessed with a disease-specific instrument EORTC QLQ-30 and its breast cancer specific module BR23.

secondary_outcome.description: Satisfaction for life was assessed with a questionnaire created for this study.

secondary_outcome.measure: The use of health care services
secondary_outcome.description: The use of health care services was assessed with a questionnaire create for this study.

arm_group.description: Peer support group received, in addition to usual care, peer support via telephone 1-5 times according to their own preference. Peer support was started at the time between diagnosis and the beginning of treatments.
The control group received usual care only. For ethical reasons, participants in the control group were not discouraged from seeking peer support by themselves if they felt a need for it.

intervention.description: Peer support persons are breast cancer survivors, who were educated to give peer support. They contacted participants by telephone.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- recently diagnosed primary breast cancer
- no other serious illnesses
- ability to communicate in Finnish or Swedish (official languages in Finland)
- ability to fill in the questionnaires
Exclusion Criteria:
- some other serious illnesses
- inability to communicate in Finnish or Swedish (official languages in Finland)
- inability to fill in the questionnaires

eligibility.gender_description: Participants were women who had breast cancer.
